key_insight: BOAD discovers a hierarchy of specialized software-engineering agents via bandit optimization, replacing monolithic single-agent workflows so systems better handle long-horizon, out-of-distribution coding tasks.
problem_solved: LLMs struggle on real-world software engineering problems because a single monolithic agent must retain irrelevant context and make correlated errors across long workflows, reducing robustness and generalization.
method: Decompose the SWE workflow into a hierarchy of specialized agents (e.g., issue understanding, code navigation, patch generation).
Use bandit optimization to discover and select effective agent roles, policies, and coordination patterns automatically.
Evaluate and iterate on agent hierarchies to improve long-horizon performance and out-of-distribution generalization compared to monolithic chains.
impact: BOAD improves robustness, modularity, and scalability of automated software engineering pipelines, enabling more reliable long-horizon code reasoning and maintenance with LLM-based systems.
visual_elements: Hierarchy diagram showing stacked agent roles (issue parser → navigator → fixer) with arrows for task flow
Schematic of the bandit optimization loop: propose agent configs → evaluate → update selection probabilities
Comparison chart (bar/line) showing BOAD vs monolithic agent performance on long-horizon and OOD benchmarks
Icons representing agent specialties (lens for search/navigation, wrench for patching, lightbulb for planning) and a multi-armed bandit icon
paper_title: BOAD: Discovering Hierarchical Software Engineering Agents via Bandit Optimization
paper_authors: Iris Xu, Guangtao Zeng, Zexue He, Charles Jin, Aldo Pareja
